issues.body:
This may have been design initially, but results in different behaviours than other ReactiveSeq implementations (which has knock-effects on IO behaviour)
Also important for #988

When configuring a reactive-stream (via Spouts) asynchronously, it is possible to push data asynchronously that is recieved by onNext before initialization is complete.

Any attempt to send subsequent requests for more data upstream should check for initialization to complete (on the initialization thread), otherwise the upstream subscription won't be available.

commitsDetails.commitMessage: add tests and impls for #1012 and #1013

issues.title: takeRight can result in OutOfMemoryExceptions being thrown
issues.body:
e.g. 
```java
assertThat(empty.takeRight(Integer.MAX_VALUE),equalTo(empty));
```

The underlying cause is the use of takeRight on ReactiveSeq which allocates an ArrayDeque of the specified size to capture the last X values. Sizing the ArrayDeque to a sensible max and switching to a LinkedList above that max would solve this issue.

commitsDetails.commitMessage: add tests and impls for #1012 and #1013

issues.body:
e.g. This results in OOM error

```java
 assertThat(LazyString.of("hello world").dropRight(Integer.MAX_VALUE),equalTo(empty));
```

This can be solved by checking if the size of the String (or List) is less than max value.

issues.body:
Currently, for reactive/ CompletableEvals Eval get() swallows any errors recieved via the reactive-streams error channel (but propagates errors thrown inside it's own operators). It returns null instead.

This is a bug. It is reasonable to expect that round triping from a Future with a NoSuchElementException results in a failed Future with a NullPointerException and not a successful Future with a null value.

Eval::get should throw any errors recieved from any Publisher to which it was subscribed (this does make mixing Eval with reactive-streams operators fromPublisher / mergeMap unsafe, likely for the duration of the 10.X.X cycle).
issues.title: Reactive Eval::get should propagate errors
Completable types block on reactive-streams subscriptions

subscribe inside each completable should be overriden to delegate to the active reactive instance.

```java
Spouts.range(0, 1_000_000).mergeMap(10,Spouts::of).toList()
```

issues.body: It would be better to propagate left Throwables as errors. This supports the use case of LazyEither in mergeMap as an alternative to Throwing exceptions.

Functions accepting Tuples are currently defined as

```java
Function<? super Tuple2<? super T,? super R1>, ? extends Eval<R2>> 
```

This should be 
```java
Function<? super Tuple2<T,R1>, ? extends Eval<R2>> 
```
issues.title: Fix Comprehensions method signatures
Mutation operations on immutable JDK collections should throw UnsupportedOperationException
issues.body:
The JavaDoc contracts for JDK Collection mutation operations (eg [`java.util.List.add()`](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/util/List.html#add-E-)) state that the methods will throw `UnsupportedOperationException` if the operation is not supported. This behaviour helps to expose programming errors as early as possible (ie when accidentally passing an immutable collection where a mutable collection is expected). 

The JDK Collection view classes (like [ListView](https://github.com/aol/cyclops-react/blob/6cc74dd3b6eada39da9039253319ce3ebc3e7ed6/cyclops/src/main/java/com/oath/cyclops/types/persistent/views/ListView.java#L91)) don't throw `UnsupportedOperationException` as specified by the Collection contracts; instead they silently ignore mutations.

By way of reference, Dexx and Paguro both appear to respect the contract in their immutable `java.util.List` implementations:

- https://github.com/andrewoma/dexx/blob/a685e4c29ec5ac6126f337dbf7f1d493d2af7bd0/collection/src/main/java/com/github/andrewoma/dexx/collection/internal/adapter/ListAdapater.java#L77
- https://github.com/GlenKPeterson/Paguro/blob/0b2496953c365455e4d6e8a15da0d7a0846f0de0/src/main/java/org/organicdesign/fp/collections/UnmodList.java#L80
https://english.stackexchange.com/questions/26158/what-is-the-correct-spelling-wrapable-or-wrappable
issues.title: Unwrapable should be spelt Unwrappable

issues.title: Incorrect Vector size after drop / drop right
issues.body: Size set to incorrect value

scanRight can be implemented efficiently via foldRight, but this does not execute lazily.
Proposed fix is to implement via stream().scanRight, this will return the result in inverse order (i.e. the intermediate results from left to right). It is more performant / efficient to do this. We could reverse this list (Vavr seems to do this), but other libraries also return the intermediate results in this order (e.g. Jool).
Users can reverse the resultant list if they wish.
issues.title: LazySeq : scanRight is not lazy

issues.body:
When using OnEmptyGet populated by an asynchronous Stream, onComplete can be called before downstream subscribers are initialised.

e.g. Using Reactor

```java
Flux<Integer> empty = Flux<Integer>.just()
                       .subscribeOn(Schedulers.fromExecutor(ForkJoinPool.commonPool())))
 Spouts.from(empty)
       .onEmptyGet(()->1)
       .toList(); //race condition present on stream initialization
              

```

issues.title: Passing Class<X>... varargs parameter causes "Unchecked generics array creation" warning
issues.body:
Varargs are just syntactic sugar for arrays, so using them in combination with generic types, this will always make the compile emit an "Unchecked generics array creation" warning if you call these methods. This happens in several places in cyclops-react.

For example, the four `Fn0`..`Fn3` implementations in `cyclops.function.FluentFunctions` (i.e. `FluentSupplier`, `FluentFunction`, `FluentBiFunction` and `FluentTryFunction`) all have a `liftTry` method taking a vararg `Class<X>` argument. Of course, we know this is safe, but perhaps there is a better way. I can think of a few:
- providing several overloaded forms (for one `Class<X>`, for two, for three, ...)
- adding a fluent API to call once for every `Class<X>`

This is not a huge problem, but having to add `@SuppressWarnings("unchecked")` hurts a little every time I do it.

issues.title: Bug in Hash Array Mapped Trie
issues.body:
Replicate with

```java
assertThat(HashSet.of(1,2,3).removeValue(0),equalTo(HashSet.of(1,2,3)));
```

The issue is in the minus method on the BitsetNode class - when is data removed from indirectly referenced (nested nodes) the new child is not properly represented in the resulting Node.

Running TopicTest::disconnectAllStreamsAndReconnect a large number of times reproduces the issue.

issues.title: ListX.with does not replace the last element of the collection
issues.body:
Hi,
I've just noticed that the method `ListX` drops the last element of the collection instead of replacing it when using method `ListX.with`.

Given the following test:
```
assertEquals(ListX.of("x", "b", "c"), ListX.of("a", "b", "c").with(0, "x"));
assertEquals(ListX.of("a", "x", "c"), ListX.of("a", "b", "c").with(1, "x"));
assertEquals(ListX.of("a", "b", "x"), ListX.of("a", "b", "c").with(2, "x"));
```

The third assert fails:
```
java.lang.AssertionError: 
Expected :[a, b, x]
Actual   :[a, b]
```

issues.body:
It was noticed when testing on AWS EC2 instances that Jackson Serilizer was constantly throwing the following exception:

com.fasterxml.jackson.databind.JsonMappingException: Type cyclops.stream.ReactiveSeq$µ not present (through reference chain: com.xx.xxx)

When troubleshooting this, it seemed to be related to the following issue open on AWS:
https://forums.aws.amazon.com/thread.jspa?threadID=229364

The only place this can be reproduced is in AWS. The class seems to be filtered out and not present. This issue is to update µ to Mu

issues.body:
Hi,
there is really hard to follow the examples in the documentation. Here is an example on Matchables:

The given documentation [here](https://github.com/aol/cyclops-react/blob/7466771e9ef93c7e028ba53d6ee652b7aea49208/user-guide/pattern-matching.adoc)
seems to be not up to date anymore since the package structure does not "match" :trollface: anymore to the last version in maven (2.0.0-MI4).

In detail, the part:

```
import static com.aol.cyclops2.control.Matchable.otherwise;
import static com.aol.cyclops2.control.Matchable.then;
import static com.aol.cyclops2.control.Matchable.when;

String m = Matchable.of(Optional.of(3))
                    .matches(
                         c->c.is(when(3),then("three")),otherwise("not three")
                        )
```

Is not possible because of missing control.Matchable in cyclops2. 
There is the same case with the Monatic documentation at least. 

is there any plan to consolidate the documentation? It would be really helpful!
issues.title: Matchable documentation


Shouldn't it depend on the **slf4j-api** instead of an implementation to make it easier to use in other projects? And why does it depend on jcl-over-slf4j?
issues.title: Dependency on slf4j-simple
Batching works in an unexpected way when using futureStream
issues.body:
0
down vote
favorite
	

I am trying to use cyclops-react to batch the elements from a queue, based on size, but also on time, so it doesn't block when there are no elements

Maybe the functionality is not what I expected or I am doing something wrong

The complete code (Groovy) is like this with the producer in another thread:
```
            Queue<String> queue = QueueFactories.<String>unboundedQueue().build();
    new Thread({
        while (true) {
            sleep(1000)
            queue.offer("New message " + System.currentTimeMillis());
        }
    }).start();

    StreamSource.futureStream(queue, new LazyReact(ThreadPools.queueCopyExecutor))
            .groupedBySizeAndTime(10,500,TimeUnit.MILLISECONDS)
            .forEach({i->println(i + " Batch Time: ${System.currentTimeMillis()}")})
```

The output is:
```
    [New message 1487673650332,  Batch Time: 1487673651356]
    [New message 1487673651348, New message 1487673652352,  Batch Time: 1487673653356]
    [New message 1487673653355, New message 1487673654357,  Batch Time: 1487673655362]
    [New message 1487673655362, New message 1487673656364,  Batch Time: 1487673657365]
```

But I was expecting one element in each batch since the delay between elements offered is 1 second but the batching is every half a second

Also I tried with an asynchronous stream (Groovy code):

```
    Queue<String> queue = QueueFactories.<String>unboundedQueue().build();
    StreamSource.futureStream(queue, new LazyReact(ThreadPools.queueCopyExecutor))
            .async()
            .groupedBySizeAndTime(10, 500,TimeUnit.MILLISECONDS)
            .peek({i->println(i + "Batch Time: ${System.currentTimeMillis()}")}).run();

    while (true) {
        queue.offer("New message " + System.currentTimeMillis());
        sleep(1000)
    }
```

Again, it only batches every 2 seconds sometimes waiting for two elements per batch, even if the timeout in the batch is half second:

```
    [New message 1487673877780, Batch Time: 1487673878819]
    [New message 1487673878811, New message 1487673879812, Batch Time: 1487673880815]
    [New message 1487673880814, New message 1487673881819, Batch Time: 1487673882823]
    [New message 1487673882823, New message 1487673883824, Batch Time: 1487673884828]
    [New message 1487673884828, New message 1487673885831, Batch Time: 1487673886835]
```

I did a third experiment with a non future non lazy stream, and this time it worked.

 ```
Queue<String> queue = QueueFactories.<String>unboundedQueue().build();
    new Thread({
        while (true) {
            sleep(1000)
            queue.offer("New message " + System.currentTimeMillis());
        }
    }).start();

    queue.stream()
            .groupedBySizeAndTime(10,500,TimeUnit.MILLISECONDS)
            .forEach({i->println(i + " Batch Time " + System.currentTimeMillis())})
```

Result:

 ```
   [New message 1487673288017, New message 1487673289027,  Batch Time , 1487673289055]
    [New message 1487673290029,  Batch Time , 1487673290029]
    [New message 1487673291033,  Batch Time , 1487673291033]
    [New message 1487673292037,  Batch Time , 1487673292037]
```

Why is the behaviour of the batching seems to be wrong when you use a future stream?

issues.body:
The following code should return 4 but instead returns -1. This is because LimitLastOneSpliterator doesn't terminate the tryAdvance cycle correctly (and singleOptional presumes more values are available).

```java
ReactiveSeq.of(1, 2, 3, 4)
           .takeRight(1)
           .singleOptional()
           .orElse(-1)
```

Since 1.0.5

issues.body:
I have some code like this:

```
Supplier<Try<Boolean, RuntimeException>> execute = ...

boolean isOk = execute.get();
```

and i want to try again and call ```recoverWith``` if the first execution failed:

```
boolean isOk = execute.get().recoverWith(ex -> execute.get());
```

but current signature of ```recoverWith``` do not allow to pass functions returning ```Try```:

```
public Success<T, X> recoverWith(Function<? super X, ? extends Success<T, X>> fn);
```

can you make it like scala version of [Try](http://www.scala-lang.org/api/2.9.3/scala/util/Try.html):

```
public Success<T, X> recoverWith(Function<? super X, ? extends Try<T, X>> fn);
```

or is there a better way to recover with function returning ```Try```?
issues.title: How to recover from failed Try with function returning other Try?

issues.body:
But won't be executed on a secondary Xor.

The secondary type needs to be held constant. Fix in MonadicValue2

E.g.

     Maybe.of(10)
                .flatMap(i -> { System.out.println("Not lazy!"); return  Maybe.of(15);})
                .map(i -> { System.out.println("Not lazy!"); return  Maybe.of(15);})
                .map(i -> Maybe.of(20));

It would be better to implement flatMap on Maybe#lazy by creating an Eval#later that defers the eager evaluation of the Maybe.
issues.title: Maybe flatMap is not totally lazy

issues.body: Maybe is already lazy and represents a value that may or may not be present.

CurryVariance supports functions with co/contra variance.  Parameter signature should look something like this

issues.title: BiFunction definition Curry2 in Curry uses co/contravariance

issues.body:
Logically the curried syntax imparts more information

     ListX.of(1,2,3)
          .forEach2(a->ListX.range(0, a), a->b->Tuple.tuple(a,b));

a is clearly denoted at a higher level than b. It's useful information, but doesn't work well with method references

e.g. 

     ListX.of(1,2,3)
          .forEach2(a->ListX.range(0, a),Tuple::tuple);

Is more idiomatic Java.

This is a breaking change, so should go into the 2.0.0 release.

issues.title: Applicative functor bug when applying a Semigroup
issues.body:
Accummulating failures starting with a Success fails to accumulate.

E.g.  This fails 

```
    Xor<String,String> fail1 = Xor.primary("success1");
    assertThat(fail1.swap().ap((a,b)->a+b)
                            .ap(Xor.secondary("failed2").swap())
                            .ap(Xor.<String,String>primary("success2").swap())
                            .convertable()
                            .get(),equalTo("failed2"));
```

Where as the only failure (second Xor) should be included in the result.
Reported by @the-james-burton here - https://github.com/aol/cyclops/issues/198. Fixed for RC4, but in cyclops-react, so this is a better place to track it.

issues.body:
zip3 supports covariant Stream types while the others do not.

```
    <S, U> Traversable<Tuple3<T, S, U>> zip3(Stream<? extends S> second, Stream<? extends U> third) 

    <T2, T3, T4> Traversable<Tuple4<T, T2, T3, T4>> zip4(Stream<T2> second, Stream<T3> third,
```

issues.title: ReactiveSeq.range(aNegativeValue, other)

issues.body:
```
System.out.println( Do.add(ReactiveSeq.of("a","b","c"))
                .add(Arrays.asList(1,2,3))
                .yield(a->b->a + "#" + b)
                .toListX() );
```

works ok, but the following throws IllegalStateException( "stream has already been operated upon or closed") :: 

```
System.out.println( Do.add(ReactiveSeq.of("a","b","c"))
                .addValues(1,2,3)
                .yield(a->b->a + "#" + b)
                .toListX() );
```

What difference is about using the 2 api?
And works OK with  addStream(Supplier):

```
System.out.println( Do.add(ReactiveSeq.of("a","b","c"))
                .addStream(()->ReactiveSeq.of(1,2,3))
                .yield(a->b->a + "#" + b)
                .toListX() );
```

but exception with  a direct Stream:

```
 System.out.println( Do.add(ReactiveSeq.of("a","b","c"))
                .add(ReactiveSeq.of(1,2,3))
                .yield(a->b->a + "#" + b)
                .toListX() );
```

there may be need most unambiguous and explicit difference between of how to use them.
issues.title: What diff between Do.addValues(1,2,3) and Do.add(Arrays.asList(1,2,3))

issues.title: slice, scanLeft, scanRight creating a nested LazyFutureStream
issues.body: Results in occasionally inconsistent results.

FuturePool is written to support single threaded reads and writes, but multiple threads can write to the pool. The main pathway is where the thread used by the underlying Stream both reads and writes to the pool. When a toQueue operation is completed however, a Future can returned itself to the pool when it completes - this is on a different thread. 

FuturePool needs to use a thread-safe collection such as an AtomicArrayReference to store pooled objects.

This is on master, but on any released version of simple-react.
issues.title: Objects can be read and written from the Object Pool on multiple threads

issues.title: LazyFutureStream : issue when using filter with forEach / collect /toList etc
issues.body:
It works with run, runOnCurrent etc
Issue occurs when filtering on in a stream that includes an operation that makes use of queues (e.g. flatMap)

```
         LazyReact
            .parallelCommonBuilder()
            .iterateInfinitely("", last -> nextFile())
            .limit(100)
            .map(this::readFileToString)
            .map(this::parseJson)
                .batchByTime(1, TimeUnit.MICROSECONDS)
            .peek(batch -> System.out.println("batched : " + batch))
            .filter(c->!c.isEmpty())
            .map(this::processOrders)
            .forEach(next -> count2= count2+next.size());
```
Current behaviour is to wait for a result, rather than timing out when batch max time reached for a batch.
issues.title: batchByTime should timeout when time limit reached

issues.body:
Eager Streams (EagerFutureStream and SimpleReactStream) perform a terminal operation on the underlying Stream at each phase, this means for any (more complex) operators ([see list of operators that are batched for EagerFuturestream](https://github.com/aol/simple-react/wiki/List-of-operators-where-EagerFutureStream-batches-results)) that require data to flow though a queue they need to pull all data in from that Queue before the subsequent stages can be started (in other words data must flow through the queue to the next stage as a batch).

This makes time based operators such as batchByTime, jitter, debounce, chunked etc. less useful than for LazyFutureStreams. Reducing the operator set for EagerFutureStream would reduce the gap between it and SimpleReactStream - and perhaps they should be merged, leaving 2 streams 

LazyFutureStream for infinite async streaming
and 
EagerFutureStream, simpler API, for processing of small batches
issues.title: Merge EagerFutureStream and SimpleReactStream, remove time based operators from EagerFutureStream
